posts.name: Taco
posts.cooked:
We had a problem at PNW Sammamish Competition this weekend that makes no sense to any mentor or member of the team. Between matches, with no code changes, our previously reliable odometry failed in a very crazy way, it looked almost like it was giving random positions on the field. After the match, we took the robot back to our pits and ran some tests using apriltag images to test to see where it would go, and it seemed to go to the right positions. Just to be extra sure, we took it to the practice field to test out vision. We encountered no errors with the odometry, so we assumed it was a onetime issue. Next match, same issue, the odometry was flipping out again, teleporting to almost random positions and even jumping off the field, which is weird because we have code that discards vision inputs if they are out of the field boundaries. This match though, our drive coach recorded the match so we could review it after. In the video, any time we did not have an apriltag in our camera’s sights, it would run just fine using mechanical odometry, so we assume it is probably something with our visual odometry. This issue kept up for the rest of the competition even through elims, with the error unrepeatable outside of actual matches. After the competition, we took the robot back to our field and ran a full run through of a competition from autos to teleop and didn’t see the issue. The next day we ran through as many things we could think of to replicate the issue with no avail, such as maxing out robot cpu to force loop overruns or messing with photonvision settings on our cameras to get a similar result. We have run out of both ideas and theories of what happened and if it will continue to happen at future competitions. Right now, we are testing faking bad mechanical odometry for our robot or trying to show it multiple wrong or the same apriltags on a single camera. If anyone has had a similar issue, please reach out to us.

Bad Odometry Video

Good Odometry Video

posts.name: Ice1605
posts.cooked: Can’t say for sure that this was the issue, but did you happen to check the AprilTag locations during field calibration? If some of the tag positions are off, that can have a surprisingly large effect on the quality of pose estimation, depending on how far off they are. I heard some events had some issues with AprilTag setup precision.

posts.name: Thomas DeSilva
posts.cooked:
We didn’t make it out to field calibration for this event due to a late-discovered electrical issue, but the thing that has us confused is that our odometry was working for the first day of the event and not the second. I’d expect that if there was a field-related issue, we would have seen it the first day, and other teams running Photon Vision would have seen it as well.

The other thing that stands out to me is how fast the poses are changing, which suggests that we’re feeding in data with very low uncertainty. We’re scaling our standard deviation for each measurement linearly with distance to the target and I’m not sure what failure mode would give us a valid target with a very small distance. With the way we’re calculating it, there’s no way for the uncertainty to go negative, and feeding in a NaN causes the whole filter to break and lock us at the origin.

There’s a chance we may have been getting bad drivebase odometry data, which the original post mentions that we’re going to test next, but it seems odd that the robot would move much at all if there was a problem there. The steering encoders seem like they were fine because we were able to drive the robot without field-relative orientation adjustments, the drive encoders must be fine because they’re brushless motors and they still moved, and I’m not sure a gyro outage tracks with the variety of different positions the pose estimator was hitting.

If we can’t get a solution here, I think advice on how to log raw odometry data to disk without choking our CPU would also help so we can get some real data (instead of me trying to point my phone at a screen while also playing a match). We have a screen recorder on our driver station now, but getting real numbers that we can plot would be better. We’re a little too late in the season to figure out AdvantageKit integration now.

lol im pretty sure you hit a photonvision bug that I spent way too long debugging. 1 line fix? Instead of using result.getTimestamp(), use Timer.getFPGATimestamp() instead. or clamp it, that’s probably better.

Thomas_DeSilva:

how to log raw odometry data to disk

WPILib has builtin logging of everything on networktables to disk. Just turn it on. On-Robot Telemetry Recording Into Data Logs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: On-Robot Telemetry Recording Into Data Logs — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: Wait what? Are you saying the photonvision timestamps aren’t accurate when connected to FMS ?

posts.name: Thomas DeSilva
posts.cooked: I don’t see any calls to getTimestamp(), but there is a timestampSeconds member on the pose object that we’re giving to SwerveDrivePoseEstimator.addVisionMeasurement()–are you suggesting to overwrite that value with the FPGA time? Clamping seems like it would reduce the severity but still make weird things happen if we’re getting bad time values. Still, this is a good thing for us to investigate and see if it gets us a repro; thanks for posting.

Yes. Also, photonvision timestamps aren’t accurate when not connected to FMS .

It’s technically not a photon specific thing but surrounds latency compensating timestamps across a network in general.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: I’m confused, you’re suggesting using the current time on the rio as opposed to the time associated with the pose estimate?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: fix latency calculation by gerth2 · Pull Request #1227 · PhotonVision/photonvision · GitHub was fixed a little while ago, let us know if you’re seeing issues with the other latency numbers.

link_counts.title: fix latency calculation by gerth2 · Pull Request #1227 · PhotonVision/photonvision · GitHub

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked:
Yeah this is a proposed hack to work around result timestamps potentially being from the future. Not sure what the pose estimator does in that case but they’re proposing that as the root cause

To my knowledge nt4 only syncs clocks at client connection. So if you get unlucky and that ping-pong takes longer than average, the result will end up being in the future.

posts.name: Waz
posts.cooked:
Here is another line of thought. I could not tell from your bad odometry video, but does much sunlight make it to the field at Sammamish? At our event in NC this past Sunday, we had issues with tags on the red side but not the blue. There were windows at the red end and it was a sunny day. Late in the afternoon (in time for finals when we were red) it cleared up. We do not recall having the issue Saturday when there were more clouds. We think it might have been the sunlight but we have not been able to prove it.

I took a look at the weather this past weekend in Bellevue, WA and it appears that there was much more sunshine on Sunday as compared to Saturday. If this is true and your pit and the practice field are shaded, this might be issue.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Vasista:

Instead of using result.getTimestamp(), use Timer.getFPGATimestamp() instead.

I believe this was a python specific problem. @TacoLord are you using python?

gdefender:

python specific problem

No, i can reproduce with Java.

I think it’s specific to Java, C++, and Python.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Whelp time to switch to labview then!

I’ll take a look when I get home tonight to see if I can reproduce.

posts.name: Thomas DeSilva
posts.cooked: Just to follow up, the timestamp issue mentioned by @Vasista was indeed the problem, and we’ve fixed it by clamping the timestamp value to not exceed the current FPGA time. (Also, we’re using Java, so I can confirm that this isn’t Python-specific.) Thanks again!

posts.name: Matt
posts.cooked: Good confirmation that it’s a clock sync bug, then. At this point should we just swap photon to report (Rio time when you call get latest result - latency) instead of (NT change timestamp - latency)?
